qas.question: In what form is the output of a logical database design?
Which data model is displayed as a specific model that uses DBMS?
A conceptual data model in separate from the choice of what?
What form is the input of a logical database design?
Which data model is displayed as a nonspecific model that uses DBMS?
What is the conceptual data model dependent on?
What terms are no longer used interchangeably?

context: Having produced a conceptual data model that users are happy with, the next stage is to translate this into a <b3_0>schema<b3_0/> that implements the relevant data structures within the database. This process is often called logical database design, and the output is a <b4_0>logical<b4_0/> data model expressed in the form of a <a0_0>schema<a0_0/>. Whereas the conceptual data model is (in theory at least) independent of <b5_0>the choice of <a2_0>database technology<b5_0/><a2_0/>, the <a1_0>logical<a1_0/> data model will be expressed in terms of a particular database model supported by the chosen DBMS. (The terms <b6_0>data model and database model<b6_0/> are often used interchangeably, but in this article we use data model for the design of a specific database, and database model for the modelling notation used to express that design.)
